Award.AwardTitle: Piezoresistive Nano-composite Sensors for Wide-range Strain: Applications in Biological Soft Tissue

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that the physics behind a new class of piezo-resistive nano-composites can be modeled using a novel tunneling/percolation model, and that the resultant sensors can be used for sensing large strains in biological tissue. This hypothesis will be tested using various innovative characterization and modeling approaches applied to an advanced nano-nickel conductive composite. Focused-ion beam and high-frequency impedance analysis of quantum junctions will unveil the nano-level structure while new nano-indentation techniques will extract quantum tunneling parameters for elastomeric polymers that provide candidate matrix materials. Finite element analysis will be used to track evolution of nano-junctions under strain, and feed a dynamic percolation model that will capture the piezo-resistive effect. The resultant state-of-the-art model will guide sensor design for employment in the area of biological soft tissue. Two biological studies will form the vehicle for application and validation of the scientific investigation: characterization of ligament response in human spines, and tracking of strain on athletes.

If successful, the project will enable important insights into the material behavior of human tissue. Additionally, the results will unlock the door to understanding a broad class of novel nano-composite sensor materials that may be developed. The proposed wide-range sensors will provide flexible and inexpensive measurement of the nonlinear, large-strain motions of materials that have previously been difficult or impossible to characterize. Potential applications in athletics, human-machine interfaces, virtual reality, biomechanics, and medicine are envisioned. Furthermore, the project will accomplish these goals while providing a strong educational focus on mentoring undergraduate and women engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advanced sensors are the enabling heart of wearable technologies, the internet of things and advanced patient monitoring and care. However, one significant gap in our current sensor technologies lies is in the area of sensing large deformations (e.g. for monitoring things that experience large amounts of stretching or bending).  This project focused on a novel sensing material made from non-conducting elastomers embedded with conductive nano-particles. The resultant skin-like composite has the unusual property that it’s electrical conductivity increases when it is stretched – a form of piezoresistivity, and is able to track very large strains and deformations. The team was able to investigate and exploit a hypothesized quantum mechanical phenomenon for creating electrical pathways through the nano-composite sensing material. As the gauge is stretched, the molecular-scale gaps between conductive nano-particles, in the opposite direction to that of stretching, get smaller. Electricity is thus able to ‘tunnel’ through the elastomer, forming chains of conductive islands that span the sensor. The increase in electrical conductance is proportional to the amount that the material is pulled, enabling an accurate measurement of high-levels of strain. 

Major scientific advances during the project included a new approach to measuring the nanoscale electrical properties of elastomers (i.e., barrier height) using nano-indenter equipment; a new quantum tunneling model of the electrical behavior of this strain gauge measuring material; and the creation of a novel nano-composite foam with a previously undiscovered sensing property. The foam material produces a voltage under impact, forming a new class of sensors for a myriad of further applications that are being developed under a follow-on project. The strain gauges themselves have been applied to the measurement of spinal motion and a concept fetal monitor was designed, based upon a submitted patent.

By leveraging NSF funds, 19 undergraduates and 5 graduate students were able to participate in a fertile research environment, with over half of the undergraduates now attending graduate schools across USA. Three female REU (NSF sponsored Research Experience for Undergraduates) contributed to the project. With carefully design mentoring, almost all students coauthored an academic product, with 17 peer reviewed papers and 13 conference presentations. The PIs also organized outreach activities in conjunction with the BYU Boy Scout merit badge pow-wow to introduce more youngsters to the world of composites. Two startup companies have been founded to help transition the strain gauge and foam technologies to retail products that will find their way into every day wearable tech, and contribute to solving society’s greatest challenges.
